passages.text: 2Q25 - profits growth meets expectation, but headline trend is weaker than peers

2Q25 results - mixed. Profits grew by \(3\%\) y/y (vs. 1Q25 - \(2\%\) y/y), in line with the JPM estimate. However, revenue (flat y/y) and PPoP (- \(1\%\) y/y) missed JPMe by 3ppt/4ppt, respectively. The key disappointment was on fee, which contracted by \(1\%\) y/y, worse than SOE banks (+ \(14\%\) y/y on average) and key JSBs. Aside from wealth and custodian fee, we noted broad base weakness in fee items. In addition, NIM contracted 5bps q/q, weaker than peers. AQ trend was mixed, with decline in NPL ratio (- 1bp q/q) but rise in SML ratio (+6bps q/q). On the positive side, CMB loan and deposits growth are tracking FY25 guidance, provisions and capital levels are high, and CMB announced an interim dividend with a \(35\%\) payout ratio. We remain OW on CMB, but we believe CMB may underperform peers in the near term.

- Loan and deposits growth tracking guidance: CMB guided that loan growth in 2025 would be \(7 - 8\%\) y/y, and the headline loan growth in 1H25 was \(5.5\%\) y/y, but if we exclude bills, loan growth would be \(7.2\%\) y/y, in line with guidance. On the other hand, deposits growth (excl. interest payable) was \(9\%\) y/y, slightly ahead of \(7 - 8\%\) deposits growth guidance. But the time deposits ratio increased by 121bps h/h to \(49.0\%\) suggesting a worsening deposits mix.

- High provision level: The NPL coverage remained largely flattish at \(411\%\) , and loan loss reserve ratio remained stable at \(3.83\%\); both ratios were the highest among national banks (SOE banks and JSBs) under our coverage.

- Robust wealth management fee growth with strengthening of retail franchise: Number of retail clients increased by \(1.9\%\) q/q (or \(+6.9\%\) y/y) to 216mn at 2Q25 (Table 10), and retail AUM increased \(3.0\%\) q/q or \(12.9\%\) y/y to Rmb16.0trn, indicating increase in wallet size. High-net-worth (HNW) clients (sunflower clients, including PB) went up by \(2.9\%\) q/q or \(12.7\%\) y/y, higher than the growth rate of total retail clients. Wealth management fee increased by \(14\%\) y/y in 2Q, mainly supported by income from WMP sales (+15% y/y), distribution of trust (+64% y/y), and securities brokerage (+54% y/y). Income from insurance distribution remained weak, -3% y/y in 2Q25, though this was better than the 28% y/y decline in 1Q25.

- Capital ratio is still the highest: CET1 ratio was at 14.00% under IRB and \(11.92\%\) under the standard approach, reducing by 86bps/285bps q/q, respectively. This is likely due to the cash dividend payment in 2Q. CMB obtained NFRA approval to establish the financial asset investment
3968. HK, 3968 HK Price: HK\$48.00 29 Aug 2025 Price Target: HK\$61.00 PT End Date: 31 Dec 2026

companies (AIC), CMB Investment, on July 3. This may trim CMB's CET1 ratio in 3Q. That said, CET 1 ratios under IRB/Standard approaches were 575bps/367bps above the minimum regulatory requirement (8.25%) as of 2Q25, significantly higher than peers.

- CMB announced an interim dividend for the first time with a payout ratio of 35%. The payout ratio is in line with FY24 level. The date for the distribution of interim dividend will be between Jan and Feb 2026.

- NIM contracted by 5bps q/q: This is worse than JSBs average of 1bp q/q contraction according to NFRA data. The NIM decline was mainly dragged by asset yield, while partly offset by a decline in funding costs. In 2Q, asset yield contracted by 13bp q/q as loan yield dropped by 15bps q/q and investment yields declined by 5bps q/q. The good news is that funding cost decreased by 8bps q/q, with a 6bps q/q decline in deposit cost and 16bps decline in interbank funding. Please see Table 3 for details.

- Non-NII declined by 3% y/y in 2Q, missing JPMe by 5ppts. Fee income edged down by 1% y/y, lower than SOE banks average of +14% y/y and lagging other JSBs (Citic +6% y/y, PingAn +6% y/y, Minsheng +5% y/y). This is a key disappointment given 14% y/y growth in wealth related fee (Table 4), and double-digit y/y growth in high-net-worth clients (Table 10). Non-fee income declined by 5% y/y, while SOE banks saw a 46% y/y increase on a weighted average basis. This is mainly dragged by investment income which was -33% y/y in 2Q vs +20% y/y in 1Q.

- Overall asset quality trend is mixed, with retail business continuing to be under pressure: Overall asset quality was mixed with SML ratio +6bps q/q, but NPL ratio -1bps q/q in 2Q. At the company level, the SML ratio rose by 6bps q/q, while the NPL ratio and overdue ratio declined by -1bp q/q and 3bps q/q, respectively. Corporate NPL ratio -8bps q/q, but SML ratio rose by 4bps q/q. For retail, NPL ratio and SML ratio went up by 3bps and 6bps respectively, whereas the overdue ratio was -1atish q/q. Risk on micro-finance loan is elevated as NPL, SML and OD ratio rose by 12bps, 4bps, and 16bps q/q, respectively. We also see rising risk on consumption loans, with NPL and overdue ratio up 27bps q/q and 24bps q/q, but SML ratio down by 2bps q/q. For more details on asset quality and the breakdown of NPL ratio by sector, please refer to Table 8 - Table 9.

- Total credit exposure to property sector accounts for 3.5% of the total assets: Management made special disclosure on real estate (RE) loans (Table 12), which suggests the total risk assets exposure to the RE sector, including actual and contingent credits (counting bank loans), proprietary bonds and non-standardized asset (NSA) investments totaled

to be Rmb361bn (-2.7% q/q), account for 2.9% of total assets (vs 3.0% in 1Q25), of which, RMB280bn includes domestic RE loans, -2.4% q/q,and has NPL ratio of 5.5% (P18bps h/h). Apart from this, there is RE exposure for which CMB does not assume risk, such as WMP, entrusted loans, agency distribution of trust schemes; this amounts to RMB194bn (-5.9% q/q or -12.8% h/h). CMB disclosed that over 85% of the underlying projects are located in first and second tier cities. Going forward, CMB will further strengthen centralized risk management and post-investment and post-loan management requirements for real estate loans. Management expected that the overall quality of real estate assets will be stable.

**·CMB will hold an analyst briefing call on Monday morning (Sep 1),**from 9:30AM to 11:30AM (Beijing Time). The meeting will be held through live video webcast in Chinese with simultaneous interpretation in English. Investors may access the meeting through "BizConf Video Meeting App" or the following links (CN, EN). Meeting ID:1183014108;Password:888888.

We believe CMB has the best retail franchise in China in terms of providing high- quality services. Therefore, its retail deposits per branch were significantly higher than its peers' average in 2024. CMB has the lowest deposit costs among joint- stock banks and city commercial banks in the sector. This should be an advantage amid deposit- rate liberalization, in our view. Rising profit contribution from retail business: Retail business contributed \(\sim 50\%\) of PBT, the highest among our covered banks. High NPL provisions provide a buffer for future earnings: CMB's NPL coverage ratio is relatively high among national banks. Also, its PPoP/average assets is the highest among peers, which should provide a buffer to earnings in coming earnings periods.

Our Dec- 26 PT of HK\$61.0 is DDM- derived, assuming a cost of equity of \(13.9\%\) , a normalized ROE of \(14.1\%\) and a terminal date of 31 December 2027. We apply an H- share premium of \(2\%\) . Details are summarized in the valuation table below.
Key assumptions/parameters
Normalized ROE14.1%Cost of capital13.9%Long-term growth4.5%Fair terminal P/BV1.02H-share premium2%Dec-26 H-share PT (HK$)61.00
Source: J.P. Morgan estimates.

Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid-cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe.
